newsitem.title: UK: NSea crudes steady on holiday, Urals still pressed.
newsitem.headline: NSea crudes steady on holiday, Urals still pressed.

text.p: Physical North Sea crudes were notionally unchanged on Monday with many market players absent due to a bank holiday in Britain, traders said.
"It is very quiet, we did not have that many customers in the office today and all those were waiting for the others to come into the market," a trader at a Norwegian producer said.
"It is very quiet with the holiday in Britain and the United States. I am doing paper work," a second trader said. The United States markets were closed for Memorial Day holiday.
A June 9-11 Brent traded on Friday at a high July Brent +17 cents, a price which some traders have said would unlikely to be matched this week due to weaker demand.
The rise of the price of Brent, the North Sea benchmark grade, since the start of May by some $2.50 per barrel has hurt refiners' margins and some have already cut runs to curtail their losses.
The Norwegian trader said most of the Norwegian grades were steady, drawing strength from the fact that there are no May cargoes left unsold.
But other traders have noted that the Norwegian crudes may have hit their peak, adding that the bad refining margins would cut demand for them.
A number of deals for Statfjord, Oseberg and Draugen were reported done late on Friday but no details were available immediately.
London's International Petroleum Exchange was also closed on Monday. July Brent had settled at 18 cents lower on Friday at $20.00 a barrel.
